photo.title: 兵马俑一号坑 / Terracotta Army Pit No.1

photo.description: Zo'n 1200km van Beijing vandaan ligt Xi'an. Met de hogesnelheidstrein, een soort space shuttle, doe je dat in ongeveer 9 uur. De hoofd attractie van Xi'an is het Terracotta Leger. Een enorm mausoleum van een chinese keizer waar honderden soldaten van klei te zien zijn. Elke soldaat is uniek en heeft zijn individuele eigenschappen. Dat moet een behoorlijke klus zijn geweest.

photo.title: MAUSOLEUM OF THE FIRST EMPEROR QIN AND TERRACOTTA WARRIORS AND HORSES

photo.description: The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. The figures, dating from 210 BC, were discovered in 1974 by some local farmers in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province, near the Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor Qín Shǐhuáng Ling. The figures vary in height, according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots, horses, officials, acrobats, strongmen and musicians. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits. This photograph is one of a series of photos taken by Julian Mason whilst on a trip to China with his family in April 2011.
photo.tags: china terracottaarmy qinshihuang xian shaanxiprovince mason julianmason prc peoplesrepublicofchina
photo.title: CHINA 12.04.11 to 26.04.11 (714)

The figures, dating from 210 BC, were discovered in 1974 by some local farmers in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province, near the Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor Qín Shǐhuáng Ling. The figures vary in height, according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots, horses, officials, acrobats, strongmen and musicians. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits. This photograph is one of a series of photos taken by Julian Mason whilst on a trip to China with his family in April 2011.
photo.tags: china terracottaarmy qinshihuang xian shaanxiprovince mason julianmason prc peoplesrepublicofchina

The figures vary in height, according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots, horses, officials, acrobats, strongmen and musicians. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits. This photograph is one of a series of photos taken by Julian Mason whilst on a trip to China with his family in April 2011.
photo.tags: china terracottaarmy qinshihuang xian shaanxiprovince mason julianmason prc peoplesrepublicofchina
photo.title: CHINA 12.04.11 to 26.04.11 (680)

photo.description: Olympus OM-2N, Zuiko 24mm F2.8 on Fujichrome Sensia 400. Exhibition 'The Terracotta Army from Xi’an' in the Drents Museum in Assen, February 2008 The Terracotta Army is a collection of 8,099 larger-than-life Chinese terra cotta figures of warriors, horses, acrobats and other figures located near the Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor. The figures vary in height, according to their role, the tallest being the Generals. The heights range is 184–197cm (6ft–6ft 5in) or more than a full foot taller than the average soldier of the period. The figures were discovered in 1974 near Xi'an, Shaanxi province, China by a local farmer. From th 2nd of February to the 31th of August 2008, the Drents Museum in Assen presents the spectacular exhibition entitled ‘The Terracotta Army from Xi’an’.

photo.title: The Emperor's Silent Army

photo.description: Rij na rij, linie na linie. Zelfs soldaten op paard en wagen. Heel bijzonder, zo'n versteend eeuwenoud leger.
photo.tags: xian china army terracottaarmy mausoleumofthefirstqinemperor mausoleum unescoworldheritagesite unesco
photo.title: Front lines

photo.description: De soldaten lagen tijdenlang begraven onder een flinke laag aarde. Stukje bij beetje worden ze legioenen opgegraven en gerestaureerd. Er zijn drie zogenaamde "pits", waar de opgravingen plaats vinden. We zijn met de kleinste twee begonnen en daar was eigenlijk nog niet zo gek veel te zien. Maar in de laatste loods stonden we opeens oog in oog met een volledig leger.
photo.tags: xian china army terracottaarmy mausoleumofthefirstqinemperor mausoleum unescoworldheritagesite unesco
photo.title: Terracotta Army

photo.description: Qin Shi Huang (秦始皇) (259 BCE – 210 BCE), was king of the Chinese State of Qin from 246 BCE to 221 BCE. He became the first emperor of a unified China in 221 BCE. He ruled until his death in 210 BCE at the age of 50. Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum, was constructed in 215 BCE by order of Emperor Qin. The main tomb (which resembles a pyramid overgrown with vegetation) containing the emperor has yet to be opened and there is evidence suggesting that it remains intact. (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)
